text: Thoughts on current Julia books.  I’ve used Julia for a year, so not basic.  How about “hands-on design patterns and best practices with Julia: ....” January 17,2020?

text: Tom Kwong's book has good reviews all around

text: I read Tom Kwong's book over the new year break and I learned a ton.  Strongly recommend.

text: The linear algebra companion book <http://vmls-book.stanford.edu|http://vmls-book.stanford.edu> ...  and the Kochenderfer on optimization <https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/657857/algorithms-for-optimization-by-mykel-j-kochenderfer-and-tim-a-wheeler/|https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/657857/algorithms-for-optimization-by-mykel-j-kochenderfer-and-tim-a-wheeler/> are very good applied julia books

text: I have purchased Kwong’s book.  The excerpts on Amazon looked good.  I will also check out the other recommendations.  The language is growing g so quickly I feel like some of the books get dated very quickly so thanks for the responses.

text: Everything published since 1.0 (2018) should be reasonable. Anything before that is unusable.
